I just really wish someone would fix this bug. Let us cancel the video that is hung up FOR REALZ. Don't make us reboot and start downloading all over over every time it happens. @YouTube

Just to be clear, this feature has SAVED me. The curriculum I teach is very dependent on us being able to watch old footage, tours of infrastructure, and "how this works" videos. I couldn't do it without @YouTube downloaded videos. 6/n

I usually make it to 4 or 5 videos downloaded and then a video hangs. When this happens, the only way to fix it is to reboot the browser completely, and thus losing all the downloads. At this point you have to start over. 5/n

If you are very patient and do NOTHING in your browser while videos download, you can download several videos without an issue. If you make the mistake of starting to search for the next video, or jumping to another tab. ... you're going to get burned. (way 3 to crash it) 4/n

There are lots of ways the downloading feature fails: 
1) If the computer loses internet connectivity mid-video, downloading will freeze. 
2) Also if your computer goes to sleep, downloading will freeze.
3/n

By "breaks downloading" I mean that it will hang on a video and never finish. At that point, you cannot cancel or delete it (even though there is a button that should work). You cannot download anything else. And the persistent downloading message will be there taunting you. 2/n

After 2 months of using @YouTube Premium to attempt to download videos for my classroom (useful if you have poor wifi or do not want students to see random YouTube ads you don't choose). I have finally figured out what reliably breaks downloading. 1/n

@bowenkerins Ah, just found the talk where I accidentally blew up factoring... while trying to reimagine calculus. There are several examples in here that might be useful. https://t.co/6NjG7XPlBq

And then, just like when I saw this the first time in my classes, they too will want to do something different. 11/11 #learning #teaching #instructionaldesign #highered #activelearning #changemanagement

Once an instructor becomes aware of this dissonance between their perception and the student perception, they begin to count how many students never ask or answer a question, they can't shake it. 10/11
We must acknowledge that it was NOT a "low interaction experience" for the instructor. 9/11
For the person teaching the class and those 3 students, they will all leave the classroom with smiles on their faces - what a great interactive class that was! 8/11
What these diagrams show us, for classroom after classroom is that in lecture-style classes, instructors are typically having a conversation with about 3 students. 7/11
For years, I've used the classroom interaction maps from Vilma Mesa's 2010 research to help faculty see a new viewpoint (images shared with her permission). https://t.co/Ed161Vj1Wk 6/11
What these faculty haven't internalized is the point-of-view from the majority of the students in the classroom who are, essentially, watchers (or lurkers) in the learning experience. 5/11
When we tell these folks that their lectures are not "interactive enough" it is an easy dismissal for them to just think "you're wrong." 4/11
They probably leave the classroom feeling GREAT about the class. That is their experience. That was my experience at the beginning of my career. And it is a real one. 3/11

For most faculty who are teaching lecture-style, the classroom is actually very interactive, even if it is not so for students. The instructor asks lots of questions and answers lots of questions. 2/11

How can we help faculty to move from sage-on-the-stage to guide-on-the-side? You won't make any headway if you tell them that they are doing it wrong. In fact, you have to validate their lived classroom experience first ... 1/11

@bowenkerins Ah, but there are other ways to relate the factored form to the graph without teaching factoring. For example, I give students graphs and they construct formulas (usually with factored forms) to fit the graphs. Then you can use decimals easily.

@bowenkerins It was just a commentary on how silly factoring is when most quadratics in the wild don't factor. I get that you have to teach what you have to teach. I just really wish we had relegated "hard factoring" to an "Interesting Studies in Algebraic Procedures" course by now.
@bowenkerins If this is a hard quadratic expression, how would you classify 0.6x^2+46.5x-123.8 ?

For anyone needing a reminder that their 3rd, 4th, or 5th act can be highly successful.

Learning takes action by the brain, and it's not a simple task.

Learning is work.

#highered #teaching #learning

Interacting with the text you read by writing down questions you have. 
Interacting with the video you watch by pausing and trying to think about solutions before you see them.

Interacting with problems.
Interacting with other students.
Interacting with professors.
Interacting with ideas and concepts.
For those who are ready, both students and faculty: Interaction is key to learning.
But maybe we are finally to the moment when more professors choose to learn new ways to engage students in the classroom. Maybe they finally feel the disconnect too. I hope so.
And let me just note that there are certainly lots of mental health reasons why both students and faculty are struggling right now.

So here we are, with professors and students back in the classroom. Students are disappointed that lectures in the classroom aren't any more engaging than remote teaching, and professors are saying that students are completely disengaged.

Remote teaching forced professors to see the reality of students that don't respond or pay attention. They couldn't look out at a sea of faces and convince themselves that all was well. From the perspective of the lecture-professor, remote teaching wasn't even engaging for them!
Professors would also feel the impact of the "passive classrooms" - many finally see that the classes aren't engaging, though many are calling it out as student apathy or disengagement.

Option 2

? - Respond
V - Value
O - Organize
I - Internalize

If your Facebook experiment is the same as mine, you'll end up concluding that we need a different way to communicate. One that isn't predatory on our time. One that doesn't brainwash its users. One that doesn't make us all feel bad sad about our inadequacies compared to others.

1. Write a letter to friends about the last few months and send it.
2. Then stay off FB for 2-3 weeks.
3. Return to FB and see whether the interactions from the letter or the interactions from FB in your active feed were more meaningful.
Here's an experiment if you're thinking about leaving but can't quite make yourself believe you will not miss it.

I don't want to disconnect from friends all over the world, but I'm also tired of being Facebook's bitch. I think the platform is toxic and it stokes the flames of conspiracy and hatred. We should all leave and re-engage INTENTIONALLY with the people we WANT to engage with.
And I hope that some of them will reply with is up with them (or make their own tinyletters).
Friends can subscribe if they want to know what we are up to and I will send out a note every couple months with pics of our hikes, dogs, and news about us.
So I'm going back to the old-fashioned letter, but doing it in a new-fashioned way using tinyletter. Tinyletter is a free newsletter subscription service with no ads and no spam.

Sometimes it is because they didn't tell us (and they probably wouldn't in a letter either), but sometimes it's simply because the FB algorithms choose what to show us and more importantly, what to NOT show us.
And then I realized that I miss this. On Facebook we get these weird little glimpses into people's lives but we don't know the whole story.

When I wrote a letter in December to reflect on the year (for the first time since 2014), I realized that it was good to think about several weeks or months in their entirety. To reflect on the good and the bad.
I actually use Facebook to keep up with friends and have been hesitant to leave because of that. But I think now I've got a strategy, inspired by that old tradition, the Christmas letter ...
